page.title: 01ROKEBY
page.content: The A66 is the main route across the Pennines from the M6 in the west to the A1 in the east. The Tees, rising on Cross Fell, flows south and east to the North Sea. At Rokeby, road and river almost meet. That the two follow a similar route is the result of the action of the Stainmore Glacier which flowed eastwards from the Cumbrian Ice Cap. The steep descent from the Pennines having been accomplished, road and river begin a more gentle descent eastwards from Rokeby and at about 150m above sea level the character of the land changes from moorland to rich agricultural. Small mixed farms of about 180 acres, some owner-occupied, but many belonging to estates such as Mortham, are dotted everywhere. Agriculture and its service industries predominate.
